title: Why the meta is ruining this game
body:
So I just finished a solid game. Fun to play, granted we pretty much just messed around. Picked 3 mages and sent our ADC top with one of them and another mage bot with a support. Part way through, the other team accused us of cheating and unfair play because we sent 2 top. Seriously? Is this how League players think? That every single game needs to be the cookie cutter mage mid, top laner, jungler, and adc with a dedicated support bot? That's so boring. Yes it's how it's always been done, but that's why it's boring. My issue is that Riot is inadvertently supporting this meta. They create champions who fit into a specific meta role, and more often than not, they do not and cannot excel outside of that predetermined role. In my opinion, this strategy of design seriously hinders the game. Not only does it not allow for interesting new playstyles with different champions, but it discourages it. We aren't rewarded for trying different styles of play, simply left with a frustrating game. I don't want to use Dota as an example, but I will. Most champions in Dota can be picked and put into any role. Bloodseeker. He can jungle, solo, go mid, maybe be in a duo lane. The point is, wherever he goes, unless he's competing to farm, he doesn't fall off due to it. He isn't punished for trying something new, only put a little behind if that. I really don't like this idea of Riot making a champion, and then telling us EXACTLY where they belong. I don't want to be told how to play a game. I want to play it my way. 

Now don't get me wrong. Some champions and heroes are made to be stronger in different areas. I'm not asking to erase that. I still want heroes like Soraka with a dedicated heal and kit centered around battlefield disruption. My point is, I don't want my only option for champions be what they were created for. Hell, they shouldn't even be created for a specific role. They should be created because a kit is fun and interesting. League has reached a point where it's champion design and number doesn't have to be so concrete and cookie cutter anymore. Yes, new champions do have some pretty cool abilities. But if I wanted to take a Vel'Koz duo, I'm sure I'd be yelled at. Despite him possessing a ton of slows and knockups, because Riot said he's a mid mage, that's how people think he should be played and will never ever view him any other way. And chances are he won't work any other way. I don't like that.

I play Quinn in every role. It works for me. I feel like people are far too concerned about the meta like it's going to win them games without trying.

Too many people just want to copy builds and pro strats and strictly follow the meta... because they don't want to actually have to work and improve. They want easy wins. That's why so many people are happy to take a free win due to feeders/afks on the opposing side. They LOVE it. It's free elo and that's what the majority want. They want to be the "top" player without any effort.

The easiest way they see of doing this is following the meta strictly.

It's funny because I'm in Silver rank (I jumped right into ranked after level 30, so yeah... I kind of had it coming) but it's funny to see people at this level arguing about people going outside the meta. Like I say I'm going Quinn mid and people lose their minds. I've had people dodge, say "gg we lost", call me an idiot/noob/troll/whatever. Pretty much heard it all. The funny thing is that I can carry the game hard and at the end of the game we win and my teammates are still like "I'm still not convinced Quinn mid is a good choice".

I think people should worry less about the meta, and more about improving their overall play. The meta really does not matter in the majority of games. What matters is who is better/smarter or works harder to win. That's the secret.

I've won games as Quinn support.

Quinn. Support.

Like literally getting no CS... still won. Because I outplayed the opposing team and got my kills mid/late game and made an impact regardless.

Will that work at Challenger levels? Uhhh obviously not... but all I'm saying is people in like Bronze/Silver/Gold really need to relax and forget about the meta... because you're at a level of play where it really does not matter. It does not matter at all.

I can't believe the amount of armchair quarterbacks there are in SILVER games. People are so concerned about what all their teammates are picking, what summoner spells their teammates take, etc... It's maddening. Focus on your own game, because in the long run, that's what matters. I'm tired of people focusing on me and watching me like a hawk just because I'm playing outside the meta. It's like people come up with excuses before the game even starts, so that if they do badly, they can have someone else to blame.

It's happened too... I've gone Quinn top and I get some guy saying "we need a tanky top, omg we lose" and midway through the game, I'm doing the best on my team, the guy who was worried before the game is bot lane and has a negative KDA and is losing lane... you know what he says? "we should have had a tanky top"

Like... uh... how is a tanky top going to change the fact that you're losing bot lane? I really don't understand people.
To paraphrase Jack Sparrow: The problem is not the meta, the problem is the players' attitude about the meta.

I have a feeling that you don't quite have a grasp on what meta means. A meta will always exist. If Riot makes some changes and somehow completely ruins the current meta, a new meta will be found pretty quick. 

People are always going to look for the most optimal strategy and there is nothing you can do about it. The current meta is fine as it is. Of course nobody is forcing you to follow the meta, but try to keep that to normal games or ranked 5's with friends who are on board with it.

People play ranked to run the most optimal strategy because it is has the highest chance of succeeding. In a competitive environment you are just going to have to accept that and stop being such a hipster. Seriously, people who refuse to follow the meta are essentially league of legends hipsters.

Not at all. Again, let's talk Dota. Sometimes there's a jungler. Sometimes there's two duo lanes. Sometimes there's even a trilane. It changes based on what a team wants to do, but is also something that happens all the time in pub matches. The league meta is extremely strict. So yes, this current meta is ruining the game because it only serves to constrict what a team can do. A trilane wouldn't work in League because of this. This isn't about "optimal" strategy, it's about champion design forcing champions into specific roles instead of leaving it up to the player. Is your definition of hipster somebody who has an unpopular opinion? Are you trying to use that against me?

Friend, no. Things like trilanes and duo top don't fail in League because Riot has intentionally stomped them out (although they have kinda) they suck in League because the numbers just don't work.

Level advantage is **way** bigger in League. Levels give almost double the stats that they do in data, and a lot of champions have passives that also scale with level. Falling behind a level in dota isn't as significant because gold is more important, and the active denial that multiple laners can provide reduces how much your enemy gets ahead. 

Unless Riot were willing to heavily slash back the importance of levels or is willing to add things like denial to the game, you're never going to see teams seriously running duo tops, trilanes or jungle+dedicated roamer. The math simply doesn't support it, and your team falls massively behind.

This isn't strictly true.

Lane setups aside from 1/1/2/J have been used before in Ranked, but every time they pop up and manage to compete with the standard lane setup, Riot nerfs them until they aren't viable anymore.  Off hand?  2/1/2 and 1/1/1/J/R have both seen success in the past, but targeted nerfs killed them off.

Gold income has more or less been fixed for weird lanes, but XP is still wonky thanks to how minion XP gets divided up.  It would be trivial to make Trilane an option simply by fiddling with XP division ratios, but I doubt they would ever do that because it would be something other than 1/1/2/J.

>Off hand?  2/1/2 and 1/1/1/J/R have both seen success in the past, but targeted nerfs killed them off.

2/1/2 was only possible when Riot introduced the new support items and face of the mountain items were so OP you were not allowed to take anything but that item bot lane. 

As for 1/1/1/J/R, I remember when that was the NA meta in Season 1. Riot did **NOT** nerf that lane setup, EU just introduced the 1/1/2/J to us at Dreamhack and royally stomped NA into the ground.

Those are just inferior setups, Riot hasn't purposely nerfed them out of existence.

There will always be meta in strategy games.  Meta is just what the most efficient way to achieve objective x.  If you change the game, all that happens a new meta emerges to replace the old one.

Saying dota doesn't have a meta is just as stupid.  It maybe has a more diverse meta but it does have a meta as well.

5 man premade goes by completely different rules than Solo Queue. The point of the Solo Queue meta is to be simple enough to pull off with out voice chat or playing multiple games with the same people.

Some people are just too stuck on the meta.  But here's the thing, the community makes the meta.  Pro players show us all who they think is strong in what situations, then people latch onto it in the hopes of winning.  That is how the meta is made.

Why do we have one top, mid and jungle with two bot?  Because it was the way the pros came up with to best distribute gold and give everyone the best chance they could to reach the late game with as much gold as possible.  
Riot doesn't inadvertently support this, they openly support this.  They support the meta because it works.  This does not mean that they are trying to stagnate things.  Look at Miss Fortune this season, she got an AP scaling added onto her Q to encourage breaking the meta and building MF AP when you don't feel like playing AD MF.  Riot likes breaking the meta just as much as the pros do (Look at Jayce breaking into worlds.)  

Yes, the meta exists and many people are too stuck in the mud to do anything else.  You're going to run into those people because they only want to win instead of just fool around and have fun.  Don't let that get to you.  Learn the meta and have fun with it, but don't forget that ADCrit Nasus is still fun as heck to pop people with.

I would say that most people don't think that going outside the meta is cheating; don't let a few random people color your view of the whole player base. To be honest, when I see something outside the norm, I'm usually pretty thankful, because it tends to be an easier match. The main reason the meta exists is that it's generally the most optimum way to play the game.

As for champion role placement and how it compares to DotA 2, I think League is simply a more structured game than DotA. I can't say one is objectively better than the other, although I much prefer League myself. I find it interesting to compare it to something like basketball: You can put five centers on the court if you really want to, but that's not going to win you games. Sometimes teams will run with small lineups (four guards and a PF for a lot of offense) or big lineups (a twin towers setup with two centers in), but most of the time you have a fairly typical team makeup. You can see the same thing in league: you might run an adc mid, or go for a really offensive kill lane bot, but either way you're still building around the core concept. And I think there are advantages to that; by having a designated meta which includes a jungler, they can focus on what will make that fun and interesting, and do cool things like the upcoming jungle changes.

I just want variety and to not be punished for trying something outside of the norm. More often than not, if you use a champion outside of their predetermined role, you will not do well. I don't think that's good design. Like I said, I want the option of maybe running something new. While I do technically have that now, it won't ever really do well because of how champions are designed.

If this is what you want, why bring DotA into it?

You can't bloodseeker support, and you can't Dazzle jungle or solo lane. All of the dedicated supports in DotA are only that, dedicated supports.

VERY occasionally you MIGHT be able to get away with a carry going in the unsafe lane, but that's relying on your opponent not knowing how to play the game well enough to punish you for it, so carries are stuck in their specific niche too. 

Tbh, it sounds like you're angry at these specific people, which is fine. But you shouldn't extrapolate that into being a problem with the meta, because it's not. I would say this game has either the same or more champ > role diversity than DotA. 

As for your example btw, Lee Sin, and Diana are both champions that fit just as many roles as Bloodseeker does.

A way to abuse this is going into the jungle with a few couriers following you, and using the heal to nuke the jungle creeps. This even works on the magic immune mud golems because his spells deal physical damage. 

And since they changed BS with the AoE delayed silence, he can now play as a ganker, carry, nuker, or possibly support. (Ganker with Urn, Eul's to stop TP, etc, Carry with Basher, AS items, and BKB, Nuker with the reworked Q which makes the target take and deal more damage meaning you can use your Q on an enemy use Dagon on them (magical burst item), and burst them down, or support with ganking once he hits 6 with his AoE silence, and ulti (which I heard is one argument a LoL dev used as hidden knowledge or anti-fun or something like that).

Jungle dazzle by...wasting 300 gold on 2 couriers, and then if the enemy ever invades they can easily kill one or both couriers, giving them a solid amount of gold and ruining your potential to jungle... Doesn't sound like a thing.

And support BS has one good ability, because Q is going to be mediocre until your carry has items (And you can't really q the enemy carry, assuming you're against one, because you have no damage). Sounds like a good way to get every creep denied by a ranged support if you ask me.

Also, BS's ult is used as an argument for Burden of Knowledge. You have to know what the skill does before you play against him in order to do well, because it doesn't communicate effectively (or atleast, didn't in the original DotA) what it's doing to you, so new players run away (which is the logical thing to do when ganked) and die but don't know why, and then are stuck doing this until they look up BS and memorize his ult.

You're misrepresenting (or misunderstanding) the BoK point. The point is that, for a large subset of new players who are exposed to bloodseeker, this is what will happen. (NOTE: This is in DotA 1, as the argument was made when DotA 2 didn't exist yet, and DotA 2 has overcome this specific instance of it.)

He comes and ganks them post-six, they run and die for apparently no reason (the dude hasn't even touched them.) and they have no way of knowing what happened. Your debuffs are gone once you die, there's no death recap, etc.

And this will happen basically as long as BS continues to gank their lane, because when they don't know why they died they can't stop it. And when they're being ganked they have no time to check their debuff bar (I'm not sure original Rupture even had a descriptive debuff anyway) to find out. 

That's not to say some players won't figure it out quickly, or wiki him beforehand, it's just saying that it will for some players make the game way less interesting because of the way it works. And that's not very good to have in a game. 

Runes, masteries, even most hero abilities are nothing like this. And the ones that are usually explain themselves pretty easily, with Taunted! above your head or something.

Most players don't really care if you go against the meta if you do reasonably well. I can work with a solo bot and two junglers, provided they gank reasonably and just don't do anything stupid.

It's when you butcher the meta just for the sake of playing something ridiculous that bothers me. Yes, some champs are better suited to certain roles, and that's the way I like it.

Your problem is people don't like what you pick.
You're blaming Riot, you're blaming the concept of meta, you're generalising the entire playerbase based on this one game as far as I can understand.

But your root problem is people don't like what you pick. You are, in other words, angry that they don't like the same thing as you.

If you had a disgusting cologne, and you loved it, but nobody liked it, what would you do? Sue the cologne company? Blame popular perception of smell?
If you love X music but everybody else around you hates it, what would you do? 
What if you absolutely love asparagus, and you went to a restaurant that didn't serve asparagus? What would you do?

Here are some things where you got it wrong, in my opinion from my experience :
1) While this was widely prevalent a year ago, even more two years ago, today people don't really whine about your pick - at least as much as before.
2) Switching up lane matchups and things like that are a commonly accepted thing. 2 top, sacrificing a jungler is probably not, but lane swaps are more than common, and unusual laners as well. You'll get the occassional Teemo mid(me) or something - and I don't hear people complain if I lock Teemo mid.
3) Your cookie cutter setup is not how it has always been done. The "meta" has undergone a great number of changes. In just one example out of many changes, 4 years ago, AD carries were sent mid. 
4) Riot is not supporting this meta or that meta - in fact with season 5, they have explicitly stated that their main goal is to heighten strategic diversity (make multiple metas viable).
5) Vel'koz is a sick support in the right hands - as far as I know, thats a well known fact.
